crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: An aloe with dense rosettes of tapering leaves, usually withered at the red tips, and a stoutish stem 4 to 5 inches in diameter. The dark-brown to black stem is extremely rough and clothed throughout its entire length by the remains of withered leafstalks. The most distinctive feature of the plant is its tall branched inflorescence with dense racemes of bright-scarlet flowers. For previous introduction see 103101. Liliaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: Seeds presented by the McGregor Museum, Kimberley. Liliaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: Seeds presented by the McGregor Museum, Kimberley. Liliaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: A bushy composite from the Cape of Good Hope, which has long hairy branches with whitish hairy leaves and large showy orange-colored flower heads. For previous introduction see 64169. Asteraceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: Seeds presented by the McGregor Museum, Kimberley. Asclepiadaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: A tree about 20 feet high, with smooth, gray bark, ovate, abruptly acuminate leathery leaves, and inconspicuous flowers. Native to South Africa. Ulmaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: An erect annual plant up to 6 feet high. The obtusely quadrangular stems are hairy, and the coarsely crenate leaves, 1 to 6 inches long, vary from broadly cordate and 3-lobed near the base to lanceolate and sparingly crenate at the top of the plant. The solitary axillary flowers, 2 to 3 inches long, are lilac streaked with purple, and the loosely pubescent capsules, an inch long, have two horns at the tip. For previous introduction see 103104. Pedaliaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: A climbing vine, native to southern Africa, with bipinnately- or tripinnately- parted leaves having ovate-toothed leaflets. The fragrant white flowers, 1 to 2 inches across, are borne in elongated panicles and are followed by orbicular margined fruits with long feathery tails. For previous introduction see 94239. Ranunculaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: Seeds presented by the McGregor Museum, Kimberley. Ranunculaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: Seeds presented by the McGregor Museum, Kimberley. Ranunculaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: Seeds presented by the McGregor Museum, Kimberley. Cucurbitaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: Seeds presented by the McGregor Museum, Kimberley. Poaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: A hairy, tufted, perennial grass, with stems 1 to 3 feet tall and narrow acuminate leaves 3 to 8 inches long. Native to the Union of South Africa. Received as Enneapogon mollis, now considered a synonym of this species. Poaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: An annual grass, native to sandy foothills in South Africa, with numerous stems and slender, flat, rigid leaves 1 to 2 inches long. Poaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: A densely cespitose perennial grass, native to South Africa, with wiry stems 6 to 18 inches high and linear, long- pointed leaves 2 to 5 inches long. Poaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: A grass native to South Africa. Poaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: An excellent native pasture grass, about 3 feet tall, with broad compressed spikelets. For previous introduction see 60454. Poaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: Seeds presented by the McGregor Museum, Kimberley. Poaceae.

crops.presented_by: the McGregor Museum, Kimberley
crops.description: A nearly stemless perennial, native to the Cape of Good Hope. The white- woolly leaves are lanceolate and entire or pinnatisect with linear-lanceolate lobes. Asteraceae.
